title: Welcome to the club all you single losers!

embed.description: Until now, infertility - the failure to achieve pregnancy after 12 months or more of regular unprotected sex - was not considered a disability. But now in dramatic move the World Health Organisation will change the standard to suggest that a person who is unable to find a suitable sexual partner or is lacking a sexual relationship to have children - will now be equally classified as disabled.

body: You're all considered disabled now! Finally a description worthy of LoL players!

replies.body: Thanks, WHO, not only have you classified all people that haven't got a girlfriend/boyfriend/husband/wife as disabled, but you've just officially classified all children under the age of sixteen as disabled! YAY.

So Homosexuality would also be a Disability?

But seriously, i think the article is just trying to stretch what this actually implies.

>Until now, infertility - the failure to achieve pregnancy after 12 months or more of regular unprotected sex - was not considered a disability. 

This is what's being made the disability, not the rest of the shit it is trying to argue.

Counterpoint:
> a person who is unable to find a suitable sexual partner or is lacking a sexual relationship to have children - will now be equally classified as disabled.

Pretty sure this is part of the point. Infertility is only one aspect of the situation, since it only applies to "traditional" (male-female) relationships. People who are single or that are in any form of "non-traditional" relationship wouldn't be considered "infertile" simply because their sexual activities failed to result in pregnancy. However, with this new classification, such situations would mean they would be considered "reproductively disabled" (that's what I'm calling it for the moment, anyway).

So, technically, yes. Homosexuality is now considered a disability (reproductively speaking, of course).
how about china where there are about 20 million more blokes than girls because of female infanticide in agricultural areas? Is too many dicks on the dance floor a disability?

There's more to be considered than the "Male/Female" ratio, since you have people who aren't going to be looking for "traditional" relationships. The main point is that someone who's seeking to have a child but is incapable of finding a willing partner for the process would be considered disabled, allowing them better access to technologies and procedures that could assist (IVF, for example). It's within the realm of possibility that such a scenario could be the result of a skewed ratio of potential partners, though (I'd say) quite unlikely.
